{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} [[File:Spiro Wulfing and Etowah repousse plates HRoe 2012.jpg|upright=1.35|thumb|right|Plates from [[Wulfing cache|Malden]], [[Etowah Indian Mounds|Etowah]] and [[Spiro Mounds|Spiro]]]]
'''Mississippian copper plates''', or plaques, are plain and [[Repoussé and chasing|repousséd]] plates of beaten [[copper]] crafted by peoples of the various regional expressions of the [[Mississippian culture]] between 800 and 1600 CE. They have been found as [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] in [[archaeological site]]s in the American Midwest and Southeast. The plates, found as far afield as Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Wisconsin, were instrumental in the development of the archaeological concept known as the [[Southeastern Ceremonial Complex]]. Some of the more notable examples are representations of [[Bird of prey|raptorial birds]] and avian-themed dancing warriors.
==Copper in the Eastern Woodlands== [[File:Anishanabe1.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Diorama of [[Anishinaabe]] people mining copper near [[Lake Superior]]]] Copper trade routes throughout the [[Eastern Woodlands]] were established during the [[Archaic period in the Americas|Archaic period]] (3000 - 1000 BCE)<ref>Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 28-9</ref> and continued into historic times.<ref name="Broseet">Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 149</ref> Copper was usually imported from the [[Great Lakes]] region; however other sources of copper have been found elsewhere including in the [[Appalachian Mountains]] near the Etowah Site in Alabama.<ref>Welch (1991), Moundville's Economy : 184</ref>
For generations the [[Indigenous peoples in the United States|Indigenous peoples of North America]] pursued copper sources and transmitted the skill of copper’s manipulation and preparation as a special material for use in elite goods on to their descendants. Elites at major political and religious centers during the Mississippian period used copper ornamentation as a sign of their status by crafting the sacred material into representations connected with the Chiefly Warrior cult of the Southeastern Ceremonial Complex. These elites used a trade network that spanned most of North America to acquire exotic trade items from far away, trading their own locally manufactured elite goods and materials.<ref name=ROBB>{{Cite web|url=http://kemperartmuseum.wustl.edu/files/spotlightMar10_2.pdf|title=Mildred Lane Kemper Art Museum-Spotlight Series March 2010|first=Matthew H.|last=Robb|publisher=[[Saint Louis Art Museum]]|accessdate=April 19, 2012|date=March 2010}}</ref>
After the collapse of the Mississippian way of life in the 1500s with the advent of European colonization, copper still retained a place in Native American religious life as a special material. Copper was traditionally regarded as sacred by many historic period Eastern tribes. Copper nuggets are included in [[medicine bundle]]s among Great Lakes tribes. Among 19th century [[Muscogee Creek people|Muscogee (Creek)]], a group of copper plates carried along the [[Trail of Tears]] are regarded as some of the tribe's most sacred items.<ref name="Broseet" />
==Methods of manufacture== [[File:NatCopper.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Unworked copper nugget]] The [[native copper]], as well as the [[Work hardening|knowledge to work it]], is believed to have come from the Great Lakes area, hundreds of miles to the north of the Cahokia polity and most other Mississippian culture sites, although the copper workshops discovered near [[Mound 34]] at Cahokia are so far the only copper workshops found at a Mississippian culture [[archaeological site]].<ref name=PAWLACZYK/> Researchers at [[Northwestern University|Northwestern’s]] [[Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science|School of Engineering and Applied Science]] used an electron microscope to analyze pieces of the flat copper sheets found during excavations at the Mound 34 site at Cahokia. The researchers found that the metal had been repeatedly heated and cooled and while it was softened by the heat, had been hammered, a process known as [[Annealing (metallurgy)|annealing]], similar to how blacksmiths work iron. They were also able to determine that the Cahokian coppersmiths had heated the copper in a wood fire to produce sufficient heat for this process.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305440311000793|title=Metallurgical analysis of copper artifacts from Cahokia|author1= Chastaina, Matthew L.|author2= Deymier-Black, Alix C.|author3=Kelly, John E.|author4=Brown, James A.|author5= Dunand,David C.|journal=Journal of Archaeological Science|volume =38|date=July 2011|pages=1727–1736|issue=7|doi=10.1016/j.jas.2011.03.004}}</ref><ref name=WHITE2011/> This process of heating and hammering was repeated over and over until a sheet of the desired thickness was obtained and was sufficient a method to allow the craftsman to work the copper into very thin sheets.<ref name=PAWLACZYK/> Researchers have also tried different techniques to duplicate how larger pieces were manufactured. They determined that the larger pieces had not been [[laminate]]d together but had most likely been [[rivet]]ed together with small copper knobs. Researchers were also able to determine that the artisans cut the copper into the desired shapes by bending the sheet metal back and forth until it broke in the desired location.<ref name=WHITE2011>{{cite news|newspaper=USNews|url=https://www.usnews.com/science/articles/2011/06/15/science-explains-ancient-copper-artifacts|title=Researchers Explain Ancient Copper Artifacts|author= White, Erin|date=June 15, 2011|publisher=U.S.News & World Report LP}}</ref>
[[File:Mississippian culture repoussé plate making HRoe 2015.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Working the prepared copper plate]] After the flat sheets of copper were produced, designs were then embossed into the surfaces probably with stone, bone or wooden tools. [[Frank Hamilton Cushing]], an anthropologist working in the early 20th century, worked out a method for flattening and embossing the plates. He hammered raw nuggets of copper smooth and removed imperfections by scouring the surface with a piece of sandstone. He was then able to duplicate the avian designs by resting the sheet of copper on a rawhide pad and pressing into the surface using a piece of pointed deer antler and pressing with his chest. This produced a sharp thin line that when the plate was reversed resembled the embossed lines of the aboriginal artifacts. This process is considered to be roughly similar to how Mississippian coppersmiths probably worked.<ref name=WATKINS1950>{{cite book|title=The Wulfing Plates : Products of Prehistoric Americans|author=Watkins, Virginia D.|year=2010|origyear=1950|publisher=Gustavs Library|asin=B004618COA}}</ref>
[[File:Mississippian avian themed copper plates HRoe 2012.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Distribution of avian themed copper plates]] ==Iconography== ===Avian themed plates=== Avian themed plates are thought to depict aspects of the ''[[Southeastern Ceremonial Complex#Birdman|Birdman]]'', a major figure in Mississippian iconography closely associated with warfare, ritual dancing, and the game of [[chunkey]].<ref name=ROBB/> Numerous examples of similar avian themed plates have been found in locations across the Midwest and Southeast, from the large cache found in [[Malden, Missouri|Malden]] near the bootheel region in [[Dunklin County, Missouri]] to others from [[Mangum Mound Site|Mangum]] in Mississippi,<ref name=AA>{{cite journal|title=The Mangum Plate|journal=[[American Antiquity]]|volume=18|date=July 1952|page=65|jstor=276247|issue=1|doi=10.2307/276247}}</ref> [[Spiro Mounds|Spiro]] in Oklahoma, [[Etowah Indian Mounds|Etowah]] in Georgia, [[Lake Jackson Mounds Archaeological State Park|Lake Jackson Mounds]] in Florida and other sites in Missouri, Illinois, and Alabama.<ref name=ROBB/>
====Cahokia and the Birdman==== [[File:Bird Man Cahokia USA.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Birdman burial from Cahokia]] Years of study by archaeologists, ethnologists and historians of artifacts of different materials found at many sites throughout the midwestern and southeastern United States has led many of these researchers to conclude that the cosmology associated with the avian imagery of this artwork originated at [[Cahokia]] (the largest Mississippian culture site, in western Illinois near St Louis, Missouri) between 1100 - 1300 CE. This cosmology was expressed as the "[[Braden style]]", a label applied to [[Mississippian culture pottery|ceramics]], [[Mississippian shell artwork|shell pieces]], [[Mississippian stone statuary|stone statuary]] and copper artifacts all bearing the hallmarks and elements of the same sophisticated style. These pieces were exported to other centers where they were emulated by regional craftsman and became the basis of local styles, such as the "Craig style" of Spiro Mounds, the "Hightower style" of Etowah Mounds and the "[[Hemphill style]]" of Moundville.<ref name=2BROWN2004>{{cite book|author=Brown, James|chapter=Sequencing the Braden style within Mississippian Period Art and Iconography|editor-first=F. Kent|editor-last= Reilly|editor2-first=James|editor2-last=Garber|title= Ancient Objects and Sacred Realms|publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]|year=2004|isbn=9780292713475|pages=213–245}}</ref><ref name=BOLFING2010>{{Cite thesis|date=May 1, 2010|title=The Paradigm of the Periphery in Native North America|first=Christopher|last=Bolfing |publisher=Texas State University-San Marcos, University College, University Honors Program|accessdate=May 4, 2012|url=http://ecommons.txstate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1129&context=honorprog}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YrsAlkuLPg4C&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=Mississippian+copper+plates#v=onepage&q=Mississippian%20copper%20plates&f=false|author1=Brown, James|author2=Kerber, Richard A.|author3=Winters, Howard D.|chapter=Trade and the evolution of exchange relations|title=The Mississippian Emergence|editor= Smith, Bruce D.|publisher=University Alabama Press|date=September 28, 2007|isbn=978-0817354527}}</ref>
Avian imagery occupied a central place in Cahokian iconography, with examples including an incised sandstone tablet with a birdman excavated from [[Monks Mound]] and an elaborate elite personage burial in [[Mound 72#Birdman burial|Mound 72]] with thousands of shell beads arranged in the shape of a bird.<ref name=ROBB/>
Although no copper plates other than some small fragments have ever been found at Cahokia, it is the only Mississippian culture site to date where a copper workshop has been located by archaeologists.<ref name=ROBB/><ref name=PAWLACZYK>{{ cite news|newspaper=SOTT.net|publisher=Signs of the Times|last=Pawlaczyk|first= George|authorlink=George Pawlaczyk|url=http://www.sott.net/articles/show/203233-Copper-men-Archaeologists-uncover-%0AStone-Age-copper-workshop-near-Monk-s-Mound-in-Illinois|title=Copper men: Archaeologists uncover Stone Age copper workshop near Monk's Mound|date=February 16, 2010}}</ref> Excavations of the copper workshops at [[Mound 34]], (a small mound located on the Ramey Plaza east of [[Monks Mound]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cahokiamounds.org/explore/cahokia-mounds/number/34/|title=Cahokia Mounds - Mound 34|publisher=Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425233858/http://cahokiamounds.org/explore/cahokia-mounds/number/34|archivedate=April 25, 2012|df=}}</ref>) indicate copper was worked there. The area contains the remains of three tree stumps thought to have been used to hold anvil stones used for beating out the flattened sheets of copper.<ref name=PAWLACZYK/> However, despite the lack of copper plates, one copper artifact has been found at the site. A copper-covered wooden [[mace (bludgeon)|mace]] {{convert|6.3|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|2.5|cm|in|sp=us}} thought to have been part of a headdress was found during surface collections at Cahokia. Several other copper ornaments have been found in nearby locations.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS>{{Cite journal|journal=[[Illinois Archaeology]]|url=http://www.esarey.us/duane/files/SampsonEsar1993MissCopp.pdf|title=Highways to the Past: Essays on Illinois Archaeology in Honor of Charles J. Bareis, Ch. "A Survey of Elaborate Mississippian Copper Artifacts from Illinois"|first1=Kelvin|last1=Sampson|first2=Duane|last2=Esarey|year=1993|volume=5|publisher= [[Illinois Archaeological Survey]]}}</ref>
===Other themes=== [[File:Etowah copper pieces HRoe 2007.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Bi-lobed arrow plates from Etowah]] Many of the hundreds of plates found have not been specifically avian themed and come in a variety of other shapes. These include embossed geometric designs, weeping eye motifs, bi-lobed arrow motif headdresses, head shapes with headresses, and plain sheets.<ref name=FUND107-108/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.spiromound.com/|title=The Spiro Mound: A Photo Essay|author1=Merriam, Larry|author2= Merriam Christopher|publisher= SpiroMound.com}}</ref> The unique "Upper Bluff Lake Dancing Birdmen" plate was found in the same burial in Union County, Illinois as a Malden style avian plate.<ref name="Broseet_a">Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 160-1, 213</ref> Several related examples of bi-lobed arrow headdresses have been found at the Etowah Site and the Moundville Site.<ref>{{cite book|title=Visualizing the Sacred: Cosmic Visions, Regionalism, and the Art of the Mississippian World|url=http://rla.unc.edu/personal/vps/articles/SECCv2.Hemphill.pdf| page=227|editor1-last=Lankford|editor1-first=George E.|editor2-last= Reilly|editor2-first=F. Kent|editor3-last=Garber|editor3-first=James |publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0292723085}}</ref> A variety of non-avian themed plates were found at the Spiro site. These finds include copper feather and flame-like shapes believed to have been part of headdresses, a human head cutout wearing similar "feathers", {{convert|13|in|cm}} square sheets with Forked Eye motifs and concentric circle designs, and several copper covered wooden plaques also with Forked Eye motifs and circles.<ref name=MERRIAM2004>{{cite book|title=The Spiro Mound :A photo essay|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lX5sAAAAMAAJ|author1= Merriam, Larry|author2=Merriam, Christopher|pages=152–181|asin=B000V6S52S|year=2004}}</ref>
==Known locations==
===Arkansas plates=== [[File:Toul Creek plate HRoe 2012.jpg|upright=0.75|thumb|Toul Creek plate from northern Arkansas]] A number of plates have been found in various sites in eastern [[Arkansas]]. At least three of the Arkansas examples (Rose Mound, Scott Place, and Clay Hill) and two others (a {{convert|32.6 |cm|in|sp=us}} found in a [[Dallas Phase]] burial at the [[Henry Farm Site]] (40 LO 53) in [[Loudon County, Tennessee]] in 1975 and a specimen unexamined by archaeologists thought to come either from the [[Neeley’s Ferry Site|Neeley’s Ferry]] (3 CS 24) or Rose Mound sites in Cross County) have stylistic similarities that indicate they may have all been made by the same artist. Four of the five were found in the [[St. Francis River]] Valley area of Arkansas. Researchers think the five plates may represent a composite creature that is part snake and part hawk as the shape of the tail feathers resemble a rattlesnakes' rattle or that the design may represent a hawk in the act of swallowing a snake.<ref name=MITCHEM2008>{{cite conference|conference=Southeastern Archaeological Conference|location=Charlotte, North Carolina|date=November 13, 2008|title=Mississippian copper artifacts from Arkansas|author=Mitchem, Jeffrey M.|url=https://uark.academia.edu/JeffreyMMitchem/Papers/1288775/Mississippian_Copper_Artifacts_from_Arkansas}}</ref>
A copper plate found at the [[Clay Hill Site]] (3 LE 11) in [[Lee County, Arkansas]] has the same chest region design and long narrow shape and distinctive tail feathers as the Scott Site and Rose Mound examples. Although fragmented it is approximately {{convert|14|in|cm}} in length. It was recorded to be in a private collection in 1978 but has not been seen since. The plate was found in an [[Armorel Phase]] burial that also contained a [[Clarksdale bell]], an item of European manufacture that is a hallmark of the 1541 [[Hernando de Soto]] excursion through the southeast. This does not date the era for the production of the plate though as such items were often kept as heirlooms for long periods, even many generations, before they ended up becoming [[grave goods]].<ref name=MITCHEM2008/>
In 1910 [[Clarence Bloomfield Moore]] found a stylized hawk or eagle plate while excavating graves at the [[Rose Mound Site]] (3 CS 27) in [[Cross County, Arkansas]]. The plate was {{convert|16.25|in|cm}} and remarkably well preserved, missing only the tip of one wing. The plate is not embossed but merely a shape cut from a flat copper sheet.<ref name=MITCHEM2008/>
In the 1970s a copper bird {{convert|28|cm|in|sp=us}} in length was found by looters at the [[Scott Site]] (3 MS 24), also known as Big Lake Bridge, in [[Mississippi County, Arkansas]]. The specimen was located at the back of the head of an extended adult burial, and may have been bent over the top of the head. Eight plain pottery vessels grave good vessels were found with it.<ref name=MITCHEM2008/>
A possible partial avian style plate was found at the [[Magness Site]] (3 IN 8) in [[Independence County, Arkansas]] along with several [[Mississippian culture shell objects#Shell Cups|engraved shell cups]]. The plate is a typical head portion with the forked eye, earspool, and elaborate headdress and hairdo known from other examples. As the lower portion of the plate is missing it is impossible to tell if the figure is a dancer or a human headed bird like the Wulfing A plate.<ref name=MITCHEM2008/>
A {{convert|8|in|cm}} avian themed plate very similar to the Wulfing Plates copper plate was discovered at the [[Toul Creek Site]] in [[Baxter County, Arkansas]] by several local farmers. The plate was located in the chest area of an extended adult who was also wearing the two limestone ear spools. Other grave goods found in the burial included a marine shell dipper and a {{convert|6|in|cm}} chert knife. Its whereabouts are currently unknown.<ref name=MITCHEM2008/>
===Etowah and the Rogan plates=== [[File:Rogan plate 1 birdman HRoe 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Rogan plate, A91117]] {{main|Etowah plates}} The Rogan plates were discovered in a [[stone box grave]] within Mound C at the [[Etowah Indian Mounds|Etowah Site]] by [[John P. Rogan]] in the 1880s. Several are very similar to plates later found at Lake Jackson Mounds, and it is believed that the Lake Jackson plates came from Etowah. The designs of the plates are in the Classic Braden style from the Cahokian area, and it is generally thought that some of the plates were manufactured at Cahokia before ending up at sites in the Southeast.<ref name=BOLFING2010/> The two Rogan plates were interred as a pair and are very similar to one another. The first is approximately {{convert|20|in|cm}} and the second {{convert|16|in|cm}}. Holes in the plates suggest they were once hung as a decoration.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Early Art of the Southeastern Indians : Feathered Serpents & Winged Beings|first=Susan C.|last=Power|publisher=[[University of Georgia Press]]|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JcEp9_6TPtMC&pg=PA81&lpg=PA81&dq=rogan+plates#v=onepage&q=rogan%20plates&f=false|isbn=978-0820325019|date=May 24, 2004|page=81}}</ref> Other plates were found by [[Warren K. Moorehead]] at the Etowah site in excavations during the mid-1920s. The other plates are in a slightly different style and indicate that local artisans had begun production of their own copper plates in emulation of the Braden style.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://ecommons.txstate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1100&context=honorprog|page=39|last=LeDoux|first=Spencer Curtis|title=Embodying the Sacred : Temporal Changes in the Cosmological Function of Art and Symbolism in the Mississippian Period, AD 1250-1400|year=2009|publisher=Texas State University-San Marcos, University College, University Honors Program|accessdate=October 25, 2010|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> These plates, along with artifacts from Spiro and [[Moundville Archaeological Site]] were instrumental in the development of the archaeological concept of the S.E.C.C.
===Florida plates=== [[File:Lake Jackson Braden Style Birdman Plate HRoe 2016.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Copper Solar Ogee Deity plate found at Lake Jackson Mounds, Florida]] Although at the periphery of the Mississippian world, Florida has been the site of the discovery many S.E.C.C. associated copper artworks. Archaeologists believe that this is because of the [[busycon]] shell trade, the shells being a valuable ritual and high status trade good to Mississippian elites. It has even been proposed that the [[Fort Walton culture]] founders of the [[Lake Jackson Mounds Archaeological State Park|Lake Jackson Mounds Site]] moved east and founded the settlement in approximately 1100 CE to strategically position themselves in this trade network. Lake Jackson trade for copper pieces seems to have taken place almost exclusively with the Etowah polity of north central Georgia. When Mound 3 at the site was excavated it yielded fourteen copper plates, deposited in the burial mound sometime between 1300—1500 CE.<ref name=LEDOUX2009>{{cite thesis|title=Embodying the Sacred : Temporal Changes in the Cosmological Function of Art and Symbolism in the Mississippian Period, AD 1250-1400|author= LeDoux, Spencer C.|degree=Honors|year=2009|publisher=Texas State University-San Marcos |chapter=Chapter 4 : The Lake Jackson Site|url= https://digital.library.txstate.edu/bitstream/handle/10877/3248/fulltext.pdf}}</ref> The so-called "Copper Solar Ogee Deity," a {{convert|21|in|cm}} high repoussé copper plate, depicts the profile of a dancing winged figure, wielding a ceremonial mace in its right hand and a severed head in the left. The extended, curling nose resembles a [[proboscis]] and resembles another S.E.C.C. motif, the long-nosed god maskette. The figures elaborate headdress includes a bi-lobed arrow motif and, at the top of the plate, an ogee motif surrounded by a chambered circle. Some art historians have argued that this plate and one of the Rogan plates may represent a female or "Birdwoman" because the breast on the figure protrudes slightly more than it does on other examples, while others have argued that the plate may represent a third gender or "[[two-spirit]]" tradition.<ref>Power (2004), Early Art of the Southeastern Indians : 103</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Birdman, Birdwoman : Queering archeology at Lake Jackson|author=Bloch, Lee|url= http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00027829/00209/47j|volume=62|journal=The Florida Anthropologist|date=June 2010|issue=2}}</ref> After the collapse of the Etowah polity in approximately 1375 trade continued for the Lake Jackson peoples, albeit now with peoples located in the northern Georgia and eastern Tennessee area. No longer able to get the elaborate copper plates from Etowah, a local style developed, producing a new style of such as that depicted on the "Elder Birdman" plate, thought to represent the merger of the Birdman corpus with a local solar deity.<ref name=LEDOUX2009/>
Further east and south into Florida were non-Mississippian culture peoples who were involved in long distance trade of local high status items such as busycon shells for gorgets and [[yaupon]] holly for the [[black drink]]. The [[Mill Cove Complex]] is a [[St. Johns culture]] site in [[Duval County, Florida]] with two sand burial mounds, one [[platform mound]] shaped and associated village habitation areas. [[Clarence Bloomfield Moore]] excavated the mounds in 1894 and found numerous copper grave goods, including two copper [[long-nosed god maskette]]s and 11 copper plates. The one plate found in the Shields Mound was plain, but several of the other 10 found in the Grant Mound were decorated with an oval central boss and ringed with an oval embossed or beaded line. They measured {{convert|10|cm|in|sp=us}}-{{convert|15|cm|in|sp=us}} to {{convert|5|cm|in|sp=us}}-{{convert|10|cm|in|sp=us}}. They had perforated holes for hanging. Archaeologists speculate they were used either for gorgets or headdress ornaments. Analysis of the metal in the plaques has connected them to locations in the Great Lakes region, Wisconsin and the Appalachian Mountains.<ref name=ASHLEY2002>{{cite journal|title=On the periphery of the Early Mississippian world : Looking within and beyond Northeastern Florida|author=Ashley, Keith H.|journal=Southeastern Archaeology| url=http://www.unf.edu/~kashley/Other%20Files/2002-periphery.pdf|volume=2|year=2002|issue=2}}</ref>
[[File:Rc11018 Timucua warriors with weapons and tattoo regalia.jpg|right|thumb|upright=0.75|[[Timucua]] wearing embossed metal gorgets ca. 1562]] A little further down the Atlantic coast was the [[Mount Royal (Florida)|Mount Royal Mound]] (8 PU 35), a site occupied on and off since 12,000 BCE, and during the historic period a [[Timucua]] and [[Apalachee]] settlement. During the Mississippian era, construction on the mounds began in approximately 1050 CE.<ref>Alvers and Mahaffey. [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:qxtQEK7fB4UJ:www.mtroyalairpark.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/mt-royal-history.pdf+Mount+Royal+Indian+Mound+copper&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESh51oqD_dCRRw5anufoWzt2OcXFlauHQDMi11ezVV6QzD_z0r_68F_DdK0MuvvqobC_zExYlWNpfVgk16CWY1Xt9RqBvjiebuBFg9War0FTLBTzjf2_vaNIsrm4o_M05G-1kMBE&sig=AHIEtbS2c8d3j4JQMvRzaH8woVkjvwTc0Q "A Chronology of Mount Royal."] (retrieved October 21, 2011)</ref> In 1894, [[Clarence B. Moore]] excavated a major mound at the site. Among the copper ornaments he disinterred, Moore discovered a copper breast-place with an abstract geometric pattern of hour-glass shapes of parallel lines arranged in a [[fylfot]] pattern around a circle with eight concentric rings.<ref>[http://www.flheritage.com/archaeology/projects/mountroyal/index.cfm "Projects: Mount Royal Indian Mound."] ''Florida Division of Historical Resources.'' (retrieved October 21, 2011)</ref>
Located in central Florida, the [[Old Okahumpka Site]] (8 LA 57) is a now destroyed burial mound in [[Lake County, Florida]] near the modern town of [[Okahumpka, Florida|Okahumpka]]. The site was excavated by Clarence B. Moore in the 1890s. During his excavation he found a burial associated plate measuring {{convert|7.1|cm|in|sp=us}} wide by {{convert|15.2|cm|in|sp=us}} in length and depicting the lower portion of a dancing figure wearing a sash, kilt, cuffed [[moccasin]]s, and holding a knife. The design is almost identical to two examples known from Spiro and a site in [[Jackson County, Alabama]], although of the three it is the only one to show a figure wielding a knife. Archaeologists estimate the plate was deposited in the mound sometime between 1100 and 1300 CE. The plate is now part of the collection of the [[National Museum of the American Indian]].<ref name=MITCHEM1996>{{cite journal|journal=The Florida Anthropologist|title=The Old Okahumpka Site (8LA57): Late Prehistoric Iconography and Mississippian Influence in Peninsular Florida |url=https://www.academia.edu/1101995/The_Old_Okahumpka_Site_8LA57_Late_Prehistoric_Iconography_and_Mississippian_Influence_in_Peninsular_Florida|author=Jeffrey M. Mitchem|volume=49|pages=225–237|date= December 1996|issue=4}}</ref>
From an unknown location on the west coast of central Florida comes the Wilcox plate, a partial avian themed copper plate showing the middle section details of scalloped wings, tail feathers and a raptors leg and claw in the Malden style very similar to the Wulfing plates. It was discovered somewhere near [[Waldo, Florida]] in [[Levy County, Florida|Levy County]] in the 1880s, where it was purchased from a local doctor by [[Joseph Wilcox]] for the [[Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia]]. It has been part of the collection of the [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]] since the mid-1930s.<ref name=MITCHEM>{{cite journal|journal=Expedition Magazine|url=http://www.penn.museum/documents/publications/expedition/PDFs/43-2/Research%20Notes.pdf|title=The Wilcox copper plate from Florida|author=Mitchem, Jeffrey M.|date=|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]]}}</ref>
===Illinois plates=== [[File:Upper Bluff Lake Dancing Figures plate HRoe 2012.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Upper Bluff Lake Dancing Birdmen plate]] Outside of Cahokia, Illinois has seen the discovery of many Mississippian culture copper items including copper maces, ear spools, several avian plates, a wooden copper covered mask (known as the [[Emmons mask]]), and headdress pieces. Three copper plates have been found, one of them been identified as being from the same workshop as the Wulfing plates and others as having stylistic similarities with the Wulfing, Spiro and Etowah plates.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/>
The Edwards falcon plate is a {{convert|37.8|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|11.3|cm|in|sp=us}} copper avian plate found at the [[Material Service Quarry Site]] in [[La Salle County, Illinois]]. Before it was deposited as a grave good it had its head riveted on in the reverse position. It is one of several plates found in Illinois believed to have been made by the same workshop as the Malden plates.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/>
The ''Peoria Falcon'' is a unique avian plate found in 1856<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Peoria Magazines|url=http://www.peoriamagazines.com/as/2009/mar-apr/falcon-soars-peoria-reads|title=Falcon Soars, Peoria Reads|author= Noack, Trisha}}</ref> on the shore of [[Peoria Lake]]. It is a {{convert|7|in|cm}} by {{convert|9|in|cm}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peoriariverfrontmuseum.org/international_gallery.html|title=INTERNATIONAL FEATURES GALLERY|publisher=Peoria Riverftont Museum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801154941/http://www.peoriariverfrontmuseum.org/international_gallery.html|archivedate=August 1, 2012|df=}}</ref> copper plate depicting a naturalistic [[peregrine falcon]]. It is part of the collection of the [[National Museum of Natural History]], but it is on long term loan to the [[Lakeview Museum of Arts and Sciences]] in [[Peoria, Illinois]] where it is on display.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/multimedia/photos/103551754.html?c=y&page=11|journal=Smithsonian Magazine|title=The Peoria Falcon|publisher=Smithsonian Institution}}</ref>
The Upper Bluff Lake plates are two plates found at the [[Saddle Site]] (11U284) in [[Union County, Illinois]] in the 1880s, in the same stone box grave. One of the plates is avian themed and the other a unique double birdman design, but still within the corpus of the S.E.C.C. The Upper Bluff Lake falcon plate is a {{convert|25.7|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|8.25|cm|in|sp=us}} avian themed Wulfing style plate. It has a mostly intact tail, which the Malden plates do not, and has helped archaeologists understand what the tails of the other pieces would have looked like.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/> The Dancing Figures plate is a rectangular {{convert|15.5|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|16.5|cm|in|sp=us}} plate depicting two Birdman figures holding ceremonial chipped flint maces, possibly dancing, and shielding themselves from a possible liquid or ropelike motif falling from the top center of the plate. Stylistically the Dancers plate has been linked to the Classic Braden style associated with Cahokia and it bears stylistic similarities to Craig A style shell objects found at the Spiro site.<ref name="Broseet_a" /><ref name=HEROHAWK>{{Cite book|title=Hero, Hawk, and Open Hand: American Indian Art of the Ancient Midwest and South|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|editor-last =Townsend|editor-first=Richard F.|editor2-last =Sharp|editor2-first=Richard V.|date=October 11, 2004|isbn=978-0300106015}}</ref> Both the plates date from 1100 to 1300 CE.<ref name="Broseet_a" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Dickson Mounds Acquires Important Artifact|url=http://museum.state.il.us/ismsites/dickson/mace.htm|publisher=Dickson Mounds Museum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220190510/http://museum.state.il.us/ismsites/dickson/mace.htm|archivedate=February 20, 2008|df=}}</ref> Both of the Upper Bluff Lake plates are now in the collection of the National Museum of Natural History.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/>
===Malden plates or the Wulfing cache=== [[File:Wulfing plate A human headed avian HRoe 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|upright=0.75|Human headed avian Malden Plate A]] {{main|Wulfing cache}} The plates of the ''Wulfing cache'', named after an early owner, were discovered by a farmer named Ray Groomes while plowing a field south of [[Malden, Missouri|Malden]] in [[Dunklin County, Missouri]] in 1906.<ref>Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 213</ref> The eight plates, made in the Late Braden style associated with Cahokia, are thought to date to the late 13th or early 14th century.<ref name=ROBB/> The Wulfing plates depict raptors and one bird-human hybrids, ranging human heads to raptor's heads to double-headed raptors on stylized bird's bodies, with naturalistic bird's claws.<ref>Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 164-6</ref> The plates were found buried in a field with no known local mounds or village sites. They had been considerably used prior to their burial, as each plates shows multiple episodes of aboriginal repair work including patch repairs and riveted cracks.<ref name=WATKINS1950/>
The eight plates are designated Plates A-H. Plate A, the only anthropomorphic human headed avian in the Wulfing cache, measures {{convert|30|cm|in|sp=us}} in length by {{convert|13.5|cm|in|sp=us}} in width and weighs {{convert|84|g|oz}}.<ref name=WATKINS1950/>
Many similar plates found in other states are now believed to have come from the same workshop, if not the same artist, as the Wulfing cache. The sites of the discovery of these other plates span the United States from central Florida to northern Illinois to Oklahoma, and include the Upper Bluff Lake falcon plate, the Toul Creek plate, the Reed Mound plate, the Edwards plate,<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/> and the Wilcox plate,<ref name="MITCHEM" /> as well as showing stylistic links to plates found in burials at Etowah and Spiro.<ref name=ROBB/>
===Spiro plates=== [[File:Spiro human headed avian plate HRoe 2012.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|Anthropomorphic human headed avian plate from Spiro]] [[Spiro Mounds]] is a [[Caddoan Mississippian culture]] archaeological site located in present-day [[LeFlore County, Oklahoma]]. In the 1930s the only burial mound at the site, the Craig Mound, was looted by locals who used [[dynamite]] on the mound to gain access to its interior. Once inside the {{convert|10|ft|m}} high and {{convert|15|ft|m}} wide cavity the looters discovered almost perfectly preserved fragile artifacts made of wood, [[Lightning whelk|conch shell]], fabric of vegetal and animal fibers, lace, fur, feathers and copper. The Great Mortuary, as the hollow interior has since became known to archaeologists, was a burial structure for Spiro's rulers. It was created as a circle of sacred [[Ulmus crassifolia|cedar posts]] sunk in the ground and angled together at the top like a ''[[tipi]]''. The cone-shaped chamber was covered with layers of earth to create the mound, and it never collapsed. Minerals percolating through the mound hardened the chamber's log walls, making them resistant to decay and shielding the perishable artifacts inside from direct contact with the earth. No other Mississippian mound has been found with such a hollow space inside it or with such large and distinctive collection of preserved artifacts. Among the grave goods were numerous copper pieces, including [[ear-spool]]s, [[Celt (tool)|{{not a typo|celts}}]], copper sheathed wooden knives<ref name=PHOTOESSAY/> and 265 repoussé plates.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/> One of the more famous of these copper plates depicts a man's head, possibly severed, in profile, with a Forked Eye motif, an ear-spool, and hair styled into an occipital hair knot from which a single feather projects.<ref>Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 142-3</ref> The plate measures {{convert|24|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|17.4|cm|in|sp=us}}.<ref>Brose et al (1985), Ancient Art of the American Woodlands Indians : 211</ref> Another of the plates is the avian themed "naturalistic hawk cutout", which measures {{convert|11.5|in|cm}} in width.<ref name=PHOTOESSAY>{{cite book|title=The Spiro Mound:A photo essay|author1=Larry G. Merriam|author2=Christopher J. Merriam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lX5sAAAAMAAJ|year=2004|location=Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|isbn=0974994820|publisher=Merriam Station Books|pages=152–185}}</ref> The plate shows stylistic similarities with the Wulfing plates. Some of the other repoussé copper pieces found include eight examples of copper "feathers" that were worn as hair ornaments.<ref name=PHOTOESSAY/> Many of the plates found at Spiro are in the "Braden Style" and are thought by archaeologists to have been imported from Cahokia.<ref name=LAVERE>{{cite book | title= Looting Spiro Mounds: An American King Tut's Tomb | author= La Vere, David | publisher= University of Oklahoma Press | date = April 1, 2007 |isbn= 978-0806138138 |pages= 80–81 }}</ref>
===Other locations=== [[File:Mangum plate HRoe 2014.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|Reconstruction of the plate found at Mangum]] Besides the Spiro site, four other plates have been found during excavations at Caddoan Mississippian sites. The [[Reed Mound]] in Oklahoma produced a fragmentary Malden style plate thought to be from the same workshop as the Wulfing set.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/> Three other plates were found at the [[Gahagan Mounds Site]] in [[Red River Parish, Louisiana]] in the early 20th century, along with numerous other copper objects including copper covered ear spools and a matched set of large copper long-nosed god maskettes. The plates were large rectangular plaques embossed with concentric circles or squares<ref name=FUND107-108>Fundaburk, ''Sun Circles and Human Hands'' : 107-108</ref> and are similar to the Mount Royal plates from Florida. A matching pair of large thin sheet copper cutout human hands were also found at Gahagan.<ref>{{cite web|title=Caddo Ancestors : Early Caddo, A.D. 800-1200|url=http://www.texasbeyondhistory.net/tejas/ancestors/early.html|publisher=University of Texas at Austin}}</ref>
Two plates were found in a [[Plaquemine culture]] site in Mississippi. Three fragments of a repoussé plate with an avian design were found in a burial in the [[Mangum Mound Site]] in [[Claiborne County, Mississippi]] in 1936 by a farmer who owned the site. When pieced together the plate was about {{convert|12|in|cm}} in width and weighed a total of {{convert|53|g|oz}}. The plate had been reinforced and riveted in several places to protect weak spots in the metal.<ref name="AA" /> A second plate was found during archaeological excavations at the site in 1963.<ref name=GALLOWAY>{{Cite book|authorlink=Patricia Galloway|last=Galloway|first=Patricia|title= Choctaw Genesis, 1500-1700 (Indians of the Southeast)|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|page=284|url=https://books.google.com/?id=2HVOImebydMC&pg=PA284&lpg=PA284&dq=Mangum+copper+plate#v=onepage&q=Mangum%20copper%20plate&f=false|isbn=0-8032-7070-4|year=1995}}</ref> The Mangum plates stylistically resemble the Rogan plates from Etowah.<ref name=BROWN2004>{{cite book|author=Brown, James|chapter=On the identity of the Birdman within Mississippian Period Art and Iconography|pages=56–106|editor-first=F. Kent|editor-last= Reilly|editor2-first=James|editor2-last=Garber|title= Ancient Objects and Sacred Realms|publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]|year=2004|isbn=9780292713475}}</ref>
==Other copper items== [[File:Spiro copper ear spools HRoe 2005.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|Copper earspools from Spiro]] Besides the repoussé copper plates, Mississippian people also created copper axes, knives, gorgets, beads, and fishhooks, as well as wooden beads and [[ear spool]]s covered in copper.<ref>Welch (1991), Moundville's Economy : 69, 168</ref> [[Long-nosed god maskette]]s, a special kind of ear ornamentation, are sometimes found made of copper. Copper examples have been found at the Gahagan Mounds Site in Louisiana and at the Grant Mound in Florida, each of which produced two of the earpieces.<ref name=ASHLEY2002/> Several copper covered cedar knives were found in the Great Mortuary mound at Spiro. Several matching pairs were found, although of slightly differing lengths, ranging up to {{convert|17|in|cm}} long. One set had Weeping eye motifs repousséd into the copper sheathing.<ref name=MERRIAM2004-a>{{cite book|title=The Spiro Mound :A photo essay|author1= Merriam, Larry|author2=Merriam, Christopher|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lX5sAAAAMAAJ|asin=B000V6S52S|year=2004}}</ref> A variety of copper and copper covered items have been found at the [[Moundville Archaeological Site]] in Alabama, although no copper plates have been found there. Moundville copper artifacts generally consist of copper covered ear spools and tear drop shaped pendants thought to represent trophy scalps. A unique copper piece was discovered at the [[Emmons Cemetery Site]] in [[Fulton County, Illinois]]. It is a wooden {{convert|11.9|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|9.9|cm|in|sp=us}} by {{convert|5.5|cm|in|sp=us}} copper covered object shaped like a human face with a crenelated crown-like decoration on its forehead. It resembles the small human face that makes up part of the headdress of Malden plate A (including the distinctive crenelated crown-like structure) and archaeologists believe it was in fact part of a real headdress.<ref name=MISSCOPPFROMILLINOIS/>

Moorehead|W.K. Moorehead]] File:Reed Mound plate HRoe 2012.jpg|Reed Mound plate, Oklahoma File:Upper Bluff Lake plate HRoe 2012.jpg|Upper Bluff Lake falcon plate, southern Illinois File:Wilcox plate HRoe 2012.jpg|Wilcox plate, western Florida File:Elder birdman plate HRoe 2012.jpg|Elder Birdman plate, Lake Jackson site File:Etowah copper ogee plate.jpg|Ogee motif plate, Etowah File:Spiro copper replicas HRoe 2005.jpg|Replicas of copper plates and feathers at Spiro, on display at the site museum File:Spiro copper replicas2 HRoe 2005.jpg|Replicas of copper plates, Spiro File:Mississippian copper pendant.jpg|Copper pendant, Moundville File:Moundville copper earspools.jpg|Copper ear spools, Moundville File:Moundville Archaeological Park 56.JPG|Copper headdress ornaments shaped like maces, Moundville File:Copper ornament bussell island.jpg|Abstract copper ornament, [[Bussell Island]], Tennessee </gallery>

{{Infobox artwork | title = Neptune and Triton | image_file = Gianlorenzo bernini, nettuno e il tritone, 1622-23 ca..JPG | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 220px | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]] | catalogue = 9 | year = {{start date|1622–23}} | type = Sculpture | material = Marble | subject = | height_metric = 182 | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | condition = | city = London | museum = [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|51|29|48.56|N|0|10|18.9|W|display=title}} | owner = | url = }}
'''''Neptune and Triton''''' is an early sculpture by the Italian artist [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]]. It is housed in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] of London and was executed c. 1622–1623. Carved from [[marble]], it stands 182.2 cm (71.7 in) in height.<ref name="williamson">{{cite book|editor=Paul Williamson |title=European Sculpture at the Victoria and Albert Museum |publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum |location=London |year=1996 |page=132 |isbn=978-1851771738}}</ref><ref name="v&a">{{cite web|title=Neptune and Triton by Gianlorenzo Bernini, 1620–2 |publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/n/berninis-neptune-and-triton/ |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
==History== The sculpture was originally commissioned by Cardinal Peretti Montalto, serving as a fountain to decorate the pond in the garden of his Villa Peretti Montalto on the [[Esquiline Hill]] in Rome. It was purchased by the Englishman Thomas Jenkins in 1786, from whom it was purchased later that year by the painter [[Joshua Reynolds]]. After Reynolds's death in 1792 it was sold to Charles Pelham, who kept it in the garden of his home in [[Chelsea, London]], Walpole House. His descendants moved it in 1906 to their country house, Brocklesby Park, [[Lincolnshire]]. It was bought from the family by the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1950, although had appeared at an exhibition at the Royal Academy in London in 1938.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55948134 |title=TO BE SHOWN AT ART EXHIBITION. |newspaper=[[The Morning Bulletin]] |location=Rockhampton, Qld. |date=24 January 1938 |accessdate=9 November 2013 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Iconography== Bernini's ''Neptune and Triton'' references the mythological characters of [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]] (or Poseidon) and his son [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]], the rulers of the seas. Neptune and Triton are deities that appear relatively briefly in classical literature; however, they are deemed important as controllers of the earth and seas. It is a common modern misconception to attribute Neptune to just the seas; however, in Greek myth Neptune is the ruler of earth and all it possesses, just as Zeus is the ruler of the heavens and Hades is the ruler of the Underworld. Triton is actually the character attributed to ruler of (just) the seas. Neptune and Triton are often depicted in water-like settings, holding tridents and usually driving chariots that have horses shooting out from the water.
Bernini's sculpture gives a slightly different representation of the duo. The story depicted in the sculpture was that Neptune was rescuing the Aenean fleet from raging seas. Bernini re-interpreted the myth, focussing on the responses of Neptune and Triton more than the actual story itself. In the myth, Neptune comes from beneath the seas to split the ships with his trident. Bernini flipped the appearance of the scene, with Neptune pointing the trident downwards and making no reference to the Aenean fleet, thereby giving the impression Neptune ruled the seas from above.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Willam Collier|title=New Light on Bernini's Neptune and Triton|publisher=Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes|volume=31|pages=38–440}}</ref>
===Neptune=== In Bernini's sculpture, you see Neptune towering over Triton. He appears to be a man in his early thirties, with a beard and wavy locks. Neptune has his legs spread apart and is balancing on a large seashell that carries both himself and Triton. Neptune only has a large sheet covering his right shoulder and gliding in between his legs, revealing parts of the male anatomy. The anatomy of the entire body is defined and the twisting of his torso gives him a more trimmed outline of his muscles, allowing the viewer to pay particular attention to his muscles and how they are contracted or relaxed in his state of movement. While standing, Neptune also holds a trident downward in motion that makes it look like he is about to thrust it at someone. "(H)e turns his angry look towards the water, which gushes forth at his feet, imposing his command by thrusting down with his trident."<ref name="R. Wittkower">{{cite news|author=R. Wittkower|title=Bernini: The Sculptor of the Roman Baroque|edition=4th|location=London|publisher=Phaidon Press}}</ref> His arms are tense, forcefully gripping it to dictate his divine power. There is an implication of wind in the long sheet and Neptune's hair drift backwards, aiding the illusion of reality.
===Triton=== Triton, Neptune's son, is positioned below Neptune's legs, thrusting himself forward to blow the conch shell. He is noticeably younger, maybe a teenage boy, though also with defined musculature. He blows his shell as a horn to announce that the king of the earth and oceans is approaching. Triton grasps Neptune's leg and ducks his left shoulder between the thighs of Neptune.
==Naturalism== The naturalism of the figures suggests the artist's intention to elicit an immediate emotional response to the viewer. Neptune's furrowed brow gives a sense of his fierce strength. His stance is set in stone, solidifying his divine power. In contrast, Triton looks somewhat submissive while he is grabbing Neptune's thigh. His face looks to be full of anxiety as if he knows that he should obey whatever Neptune commands him to do. His timid nature and Neptune's dominate presence display the reality of human emotion and brings back the point of Bernini's plan to convey myths coming to life.
Bernini gave the audience the chance to "see" these gods in person; in movement. This was Bernini's first sculpture to " …work where the silhouette is broken, where the climax of a transitory action is given and where the action extends beyond the physical limits."<ref name="R. Wittkower"/> The point of the sculpture is to bring the viewer to face a myth or story to be true and real by its dramatic tension in the body positions and subtle hints at natural life. He was making the myths, rumours and stories an opportunity to be true and demand its viewer to believe in its truth.
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Detail of Triton from Bernini's Neptune and Triton, 1622-3.JPG|Detail of Triton from Bernini's ''Neptune and Triton'' Image:Bernini's Neptune and Triton, 1622-3.JPG|Bernini's ''Neptune and Triton'' (front view) Image:Bernini's Neptune and Triton, 1622-3 (2).JPG|Bernini's ''Neptune and Triton'' (side view) </gallery>
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Avery |first=Charles |title= Bernini: Genius of the Baroque |publisher=Thames and Hudson |location=London |year=1997 |isbn=9780500286333}} * {{cite book|last=Baldinucci |first=Filippo |title=The Life of Bernini |publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |location=University Park |year=2006 |isbn=9780271730769}} * {{cite book|last=Bernini |first=Domenico |title=The Life of Giano Lorenzo Bernini |publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |location=University Park |year=2011 |isbn=9780271037486}} * {{cite book|last=Mormando |first=Franco |title=Bernini: His Life and His Rome |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |year=2011 |isbn=9780226538525}} * {{cite book|last=Wittkower |first=Rudolf |title=Gian Lorenzo Bernini: The Sculptor of the Roman Baroque |publisher=Phaidon Press |location=London |year=1955 |isbn=9780801414305}} {{refend}}

revision.text:
[[File:Disque newton.png|thumb|Color distribution of a Newton disc.]]
The '''Newton disc''' is a well-known physics experiment with a rotating disc with segments in different colors (usually Newton's primary colors: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet) appearing as white (or off-white or gray) when it spins very fast.
This type of mix of light stimuli is called temporal optical mixing, a version of additive-averaging mixing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huevaluechroma.com/044.php|title=Additive mixing, additive-averaging|last=Briggs|first=David|date=2012-08-12|website=The Dimensions of Colour|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-11}}</ref>
Many modern sources state that [[Isaac Newton]] himself used a disc with colored sectors to demonstrate how white light was actually the compound of the primary colors. However, none seem to refer to a historical source for this.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
[[Ptolemy]] and [[Ibn al-Haytham]] described additive optical mixing with turning wheels and spinning tops hundreds of years before Newton, but they did not use primary colors to get the (off-)white result of the Newton disc.
Transparent variations for [[magic lantern]] projection have been produced.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://physics.kenyon.edu/EarlyApparatus/Optics/Newtons_Color_Wheel/Newtons_Color_Wheel.html|title=Newton's Color Wheel|last=Greenslade, Jr.|first=Thomas B.|date=|website=Instruments for Natural Philosophy, [[Kenyon College]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-11}}</ref>
==History== Around CE 165 [[Ptolemy]] described in his book ''[[Optics (Ptolemy)|Optics]]'' a rotating potter's wheel with different colors on it. He noted how the different colors of sectors mixed together into one color and how dots appeared as circles when the wheel was spinning very fast. When lines are drawn across the axis of the disc they make the whole surface appear to be of a uniform color. "The visual impression that is created in the first revolution is invariably followed by repeated instances that subsequently produce an identical impression. This also happens in the case of shooting stars, whose light seems distended on account of their speed of motion, all according to the amount of perceptible distance it passes along with the sensible impression that arises in the visual faculty."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=ASILAAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA43&ots=l7oKmVwhW5&dq=ptolemy%20potter's%20wheel&pg=PA43#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Ptolemy and the Foundations of Ancient Mathematical Optics: A Source Based Guided Study|last=Smith|first=A. Mark|date=1999|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=9780871698933|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=A. Mark|date=1996|title=Ptolemy's Theory of Visual Perception: An English Translation of the "Optics" with Introduction and Commentary|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/3231951|journal=Transactions of the American Philosophical Society|volume=86|issue=2|pages=iii–300|doi=10.2307/3231951}}</ref>
[[Porphyry (philosopher)|Porphyry]] (circa 243-305) wrote in his commentary on Ptolemy's ''Harmonics'' how the senses are not stable but confused and inaccurate. Certain intervals between repeated impressions are not detected. A white or black spot on a spinning cone (or top) appears as a circle of that color and a line on the top makes the whole surface appear in that color. "Because of the swiftness of the movement we receive the impression of the line on every part of the cone as the line moves."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=c6QKDgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA137&dq=ptolemy%20spinning%20top&pg=PA137#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Porphyry's Commentary on Ptolemy's Harmonics: A Greek Text and Annotated Translation|date=2015-09-15|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781316239681|language=en}}</ref>
In the 11th century Ibn al-Haytam, who was familiar with Ptolemy's writings, described how colored lines on a spinning top could not be discerned as different colors but appeared as one new color composed of all of the colors of the lines. He deducted that sight needs some time to discern a color. al-Haytam also noted that the top appeared motionless when spun extremely quick "for none of its points remains fixed in the same spot for any perceptible time".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=3x0LAAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA639&ots=bID4ipQ84C&dq=ptolemy%20optics%20color%20rotating%20wheel&pg=PA444#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Alhacen's Theory of Visual Perception: A Critical Edition, with English Translation and Commentary, of the First Three Books of Alhacen's De Aspectibus, the Medieval Latin Version of Ibn Al-Haytham's Kitab Al-Manazir|last=Alhazen|last2=Smith|first2=A. Mark|date=2001|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=9780871699145|language=en}}</ref>
On 6 February 1671/72 Isaac Newton wrote a paper about the experiments he had been conducting since 1666 with the [[refraction]] of light through glass prisms. He concluded that the different refracted rays of light - well parted from others - could not be changed by further refraction, nor by reflection or other means, except through mixture with other rays. He thus found the seven primary colors red, orange, yellow, green, blue, "a violet-purple" and indigo. When mixing these rays he found that "the most surprising and wonderful composition was that of whiteness" requiring all the primary colors "mixed in a due proportion".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Newton|first=Isaac|date=1671|title=A Letter of Mr. Isaac Newton, Professor of the Mathematicks in the University of Cambridge; Containing His New Theory about Light and Colors: Sent by the Author to the Publisher from Cambridge, Febr. 6. 1671/72; In Order to be Communicated to the R. Society|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/101125|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society|volume=6|pages=3075–3087}}</ref>
In his book ''[[Opticks]]'' (1704) Newton describes a device with prisms, a lens and a large moving comb with teeth causing alternating colors to be projected successively. "But if I so much accelerated the Motion, that the Colours by reason of their quick Succession could not be distinguished from one another, the Appearance of the single Colours ceased. There was no red, no yellow, no green, no blue, nor purple to be seen any longer, but from a Confusion of them all there arose one uniform white Colour."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=GnAFAAAAQAAJ&dq|title=Opticks:: Or, A Treatise of the Reflections, Refractions, Inflections and Colours of Light|last=Newton|first=Sir Isaac|date=1730|publisher=William Innys at the West-End of St. Paul's.|language=en}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Publication history of ''The Ego and Its Own''}} [[File:Ein1844v2.png|thumb|Cover of the [[German language]] first edition, published in Leipzig in 1844.]] ''[[The Ego and Its Own]]'' ({{lang-de|Der Einzige und sein Eigentum}}) is a [[philosophy|philosophical]] work by [[German language|German]] philosopher [[Max Stirner]] (1806-1856), first published in 1844.
==First editions== [[File:The Ego and Its Own - Tsuji Jun translation.jpg|thumb|right|Cover of Tsuji Jun's Japanese first edition (1920)]] ===Original in German=== * The original [[German language|German]] edition appeared in October 1844 in [[Leipzig]]. ===Translations (chronologically)=== * [[French language|French]] (''L'unique et sa propriété'', 1899), * [[Danish language|Danish]] (''Den Eneste og hans Ejendom'', 1901), * [[Spanish language|Spanish]] (''El único y su propiedad'', 1901), * [[Italian language|Italian]] (''L'unico e la sua proprietà'', 1902), * [[Russian language|Russian]] (''Edinstvennyj i ego dostojanie'', 1906), * [[English language|English]] (''The Ego and His Own'', 1907), * [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (''De Eenige en z'n Eigendom'', 1907), * [[Swedish language|Swedish]] (''Den ende och hans egendom'', 1910), * [[Japanese language|Japanese]] (''Yuiitsusha to sono shoyû'', 1920), * [[Serbo-croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]] (''Jedini i njegovo vlastništvo'', 1976), * [[Catalan language|Catalan]] (''L'únic i la seva propietat'', 1986). * [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] (''Az egyetlen és tulajdona'', 1991). (Second part only) * [[Greek language|Greek]] (''O μοναδικός και το δικό του'', 2002), * [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (''O Único e a sua propriedade'', 2004), * [[Polish language|Polish]] (''Jedyny i jego własność'', 2005), * [[Czech language|Czech]] (''Jediný a jeho vlastnictví'', 2010).
==English editions== [[File:Den ende.png|thumb|right|''Den ende och hans egendom'' – a 1911 Swedish edition, with a foreword by [[Georg Brandes]] and afterword by [[Albert Jensen (anarchist)|Albert Jensen]].]] ===First edition (1907)=== * The first English Language Edition appeared in 1907; it was a translation by the [[United States|American]] [[individualist anarchism|individualist anarchist]], [[Steven T. Byington]] with an introduction by [[James L. Walker]]. The publisher was [[Benjamin R. Tucker]], [[New York City]]. This edition was reprinted several times by several publishers in New York and [[London]] up to 1931.
===Libertarian Book Club edition (1963)=== * The 1963 [[Libertarian Book Club]] edition is a re-print of the 1907 Byington translation. Edited by [[James J. Martin]] and with a cover by the son of [[Rudolf Rocker]], the edition revived interest in Stirner as an influence on [[anarchism]] and related ideologies and brought [[Max Stirner]] to a wider audience in the [[English-speaking world]]. This edition was reprinted several times by several publishers in the [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom]] up to 1993, sometimes with a preface by Sidney E. Parker.
===Harper & Row - Readings in Fascist, Racist and Elitist Ideology (1971)=== * An [[abridged]] English edition of the Byington translation revised, selected and annotated by John Carroll. [[New York City]] / [[London]]: [[Harper & Row]] 1971. 266 pp. The book appeared in a series "Roots of the Right. Readings in [[Fascist]], [[Racist]] and [[Elitist]] [[Ideology]]", together with writings by [[Gobineau]], [[Alfred Rosenberg]], [[Joseph de Maistre|de Maistre]], [[Maurras]]. The text consists of a mix of about a hundred quotations from ''The Ego'' (and some from Stirner's minor writings), reducing the volume by about a half. The reason why Stirner's work was selected for this series remains unclear given the book's fierce anti-authoritarianism and emphasis on the sovereignty of the individual.
===Rebel Press edition (1993)=== * The 1993 Rebel Press, [[London]] edition is an unabridged republication of the 1963 re-print of the 1907 Byington translation by the Libertarian Book Club. The Rebel Press, [[London]] edition has a cover design from [[anarchist]] [[artist]] and [[cartoonist]], [[Clifford Harper]] and a preface by Sidney E. Parker.
===Cambridge University press edition (1995)=== * The [[Cambridge University]] press edition (ed. David Leopold, 1995) is a revised version of the original 1907 Byington translation with a new introduction by David Leopold. Leopold changed the title (His to Its) "not out of ahistorical considerations of 'political correctness' but because [[Stirner]] clearly identifies the egoistic subject as prior to gender" (p. xl). While Leopold accepted the Byington translation as "an heroic attempt to convey the readable yet idiosyncratic prose of [[Stirner]]'s original", he "made a number of amendments, such as removing infelicities and archaisms, replacing the occasional missing sentence, and restoring some of the original paragraph and sections breaks." (p. xxxix)
===Underworld Amusements edition (2017)=== * [[Individualist Anarchism|Individual Anarchist]] writer and historian Wolfi Landstreicher began his completely new translation in 2010, and published under the more literal title of "The Unique and Its Property." All prior published editions had been reproductions of, or based on the Byington translation, but Landstreicher's work constitutes the second full translation ever completed. He also wrote an introduction to it.
== Other language editions ==
===German=== *''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum.'' Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1845 [Oct. 1844] (original, [[First_edition#First_edition|first edition]]) *''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum.'' 2. Auflage. Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1882 *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' Einführung Paul Lauterbach. Leipzig: Reclams Universalbibliothek 1893ff *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' 3. Auflage. Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1901 *several editions in the 1920s by various publishers *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' Nachwort Ahlrich Meyer. Stuttgart: Reclams Universalbibliothek 1972ff *several editions (some abridged) since 1968 by various publishers
===French=== *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |location=Paris |publisher=P.-V. Stock |year=1899| oclc=37909006}} *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |editor=Robert L Reclaire |type=Microfilm |location=Paris |publisher=P.V. Stock |year=1900 |oclc=24025908}} *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |location=Paris |publisher=Éditions Stock |year=1978 |isbn=2-234-00812-3 |oclc=20116578}}
===Russian=== *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego dostojanie |location=Moscow |publisher=V.M. Sadlina |year=1907 |oclc=45359741}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |location=Saint Petersburg |publisher=Biblioteka "Svi︠e︡tocha" |year=1907 |edition=Izd. kommentirovannoe |OCLC=16165785}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego dostojanie |location=Saint Petersburg |publisher=Tip. "Sirīus" |year=1910 |oclc=241310993}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |editor=M Kronenberg |location=[[Paul Avrich Collection]] ([[Library of Congress]]) |publisher=Izd. "Rabochee kn-vo" |year=1922|oclc=32203218}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |location=Kharkov |publisher=Osnova |year=1994 |isbn=5-7768-0265-2 |oclc=32896618}}
==Online editions== {{wikisource|The Ego and Its Own|''The Ego and Its Own''}} * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/msee.html ''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum''], original German, with concordance of three editions. * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/poly/enee.html ''The Ego and Its Own''], English, based on Tucker's edition, with concordance of three editions. * [http://www.df.lth.se/~triad/stirner/ Electronic text versions of the book] * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/poly/enrec.html Stirner's Critics] - Stirner's reply to his critics, bilingual (addendum to ''The Ego'')

{{Infobox organization |name = The Rehearsal Club |Purpose = Residence for Women and Girls of The Stage |image = |image_border = |size = |formation = 1913 |type = Young Women's Residence |headquarters = 218-220 West 46th Street
[[New York, NY]] |location = [[United States]] |language = [[English language|English]] |leader_title = Founder |leader_name = Jean "Daisy" Greer |website = http://www.rehearsalclubnyc.com }} The '''Rehearsal Club''' was a theatrical girls' boarding house was founded in 1913 by Jean "Daisy" Greer, daughter of New York's Episcopal bishop, and Episcopal Deaconess Jane Harriss Hall. The residence provided young women pursuing a life in the theater a place to rest between auditions, along with opportunities to socialize and receive simple meals.NY Times, July, 1913, https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/07/06/100633752.pdf Within a year, the Professional Children’s School was established in back parlors of The Rehearsal Club.Professional Children’s School, From the Archives, 2012, by John Tucker ==History== In 1920, the Club relocated from its first home on West 46th Street to a large house on West 45th to accommodate increasing residency. In 1923, the Club moved to 47 West 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, where it remained for over 50 years. The brownstone and its neighbor number 45, acquired for the Club in 1925, were owned by Rockefeller family members. In 1936, The Rehearsal Club served as the inspiration behind [[Edna Ferber]] and [[George S. Kaufman|George S. Kaufman's]] play, ''[[Stage Door]]'' which opened on October 20, 1936 at the Music Box Theater.Elita Wilson, October 21, 1936 In 1937, the RKO film version of ''Stage Door'' was released, featuring [[Katharine Hepburn]] and [[Ginger Rogers]].Published The New York Times, October 8, 1937 by Frank S. Nugent. One of the most noted Rehearsal Club residents was [[Carol Burnett]]. In 1955, she initiated and was featured in a showcase of her fellow Club friends called 'The Rehearsal Club Revue,'[http://www.shemadeit.org/meet/biography.aspx?m=93 The Paley Center for Media | She Made It | Carol Burnett] which served as an initial career boost for several of the girls. Ms. Burnett sponsored scholarships for Club residents in the 1960s, and fondly recalls her Club life in her memoirs ''This Time Together'' ''This Time Together'' by Carol Burnett, published Harmony Books (April 6, 2010) and ''One More Time: A Memoir''.''One More Time: A Memoir'' by Carol Burnett, Publisher: Random House, c1986 Although men were not allowed upstairs, many did hang out in the Rehearsal Club’s first-floor parlor.Published The New York Times, July 6, 1913, retrieved August, 2012 [[James Dean]], before he became a Hollywood legend, often visited the Rehearsal Club and for a time dated resident [[Liz Sheridan]], also known as "Dizzy," then a 23-year-old fledgling dancer on the Milton Berle Show."People Magazine": An Affair to Remember, by Michael A. Lipton, June 24, 1996 Vol. 45 No. 25. http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20141628,00.htmlPublished as the “saddest site today,” [http://our.tentativetimes.net/olddean/magdalin.html James Dean Walking Tours, In Search of a Legend in New York], December 7, 2001, In 1979, [[Rockefeller Brothers Fund]] sold the buildings at 45–47 West 53rd Street to [[American Folk Art Museum]][http://www.folkartmuseum.org/history American Folk Art Museum] and the Rehearsal Club closed for good.Life Magazine, April, 1979 == Today == In 2007, Rehearsal Club alumnae gathered and formed an organization with a mission statement to "preserve the name of The Rehearsal Club, protect its legacy and inspire other younger generations".http://www.rehearsalclubnyc.com == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:1913 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1979 disestablishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:20th-century theatre]]

"'''The 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time'''" is a feature published by the American magazine ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' in August 2015.<ref name="rollingstone">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-songwriters|title=The 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> The list presented was compiled based on the magazine's [[music criticism|music critics]]. It predominantly features American and English songwriters of the rock era.<ref name="newsday">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/retirement/rolling-stone-lists-100-greatest-songwriters-1.10753971|title=Rolling Stone lists 100 greatest songwriters|website=[[Newsday]]|first=Peter|last=King|date=August 27, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Top 10 songwriters== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%" |- ! Rank ! class="unsortable"| Image ! Name ! Lifetime ! First single written |- | align="center"| 1 | [[File:Bob Dylan - Azkena Rock Festival 2010 2.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Bob|Dylan}} | May 24, 1941 – present | "[[Mixed-Up Confusion]]" (1962), released by himself |- | align="center"| 2 | [[File:Paul McCartney black and white 2010.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Paul|McCartney}} | June 18, 1942 – present |rowspan=2| "[[Love Me Do]]"/"[[P.S. I Love You (Beatles song)|P.S. I Love You]]" (1962), released by [[the Beatles]] |- | align="center"| 3 | [[File:JohnLennonpeace.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|John|Lennon}} | October 9, 1940 – December 8, 1980 |- | align="center"| 4 | [[File:Chuck Berry 1957.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Chuck|Berry}} | October 18, 1926 – March 18, 2017 | "[[Maybellene]]" (1955), released by himself |- | align="center"| 5 | [[File:Smokey Robinson 2.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Smokey|Robinson}} | February 19, 1940 – present | "Got a Job" (1958), released by [[the Miracles]] |- | align="center"| 6 | [[File:Jagger-Richards.jpg|75px]] | {{Sort|Jagger|[[Jagger/Richards|Mick Jagger / Keith Richards]]}} | July 26, 1943 – present / December 18, 1943 – present | "[[Tell Me (The Rolling Stones song)|Tell Me]]" (1964), released by [[the Rolling Stones]] |- | align="center"| 7 | [[File:CaroleKingHWOFDec2012.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Carole|King}} / [[Gerry Goffin]] | February 9, 1942 – present / February 11, 1939 – June 19, 2014 | "[[Will You Love Me Tomorrow]]" (1960), released by [[the Shirelles]] |- | align="center"| 8 | [[File:Paul Simon at the 9-30 Club (b).jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Paul|Simon}} | October 13, 1941 – present | "Hey Schoolgirl" (1957), released by [[Simon & Garfunkel]] (then known as Tom & Jerry) |- | align="center"| 9 | [[File:1974 Joni Mitchell.jpg|75px]] | {{Sortname|Joni|Mitchell}} | November 7, 1943 – present | "Urge For Going" (1966), released by [[Tom Rush]] |- | align="center"| 10 | [[File:Stevie Wonder 1973.JPG|75px]] | {{Sortname|Stevie|Wonder}} | May 13, 1950 – present | "Kiss Me Baby" (1968), released by himself |- |}
==Reception== The list received mixed response from fellow publications. Writing for ''[[Flavorwire]]'', Judy Berman criticized the selection of the songwriters, saying "Predictably, it's over 70% white and features only nine solo female songwriters (five other women are included as part of mixed-gender writing teams). Classic rock is overrepresented; every other genre and subgenre of popular music is underrepresented."<ref name="flavorwire">{{cite web|url=http://flavorwire.com/532955/does-rolling-stone-know-it-declared-songwriting-dead|work=[[Flavorwire]]|title=Does ‘Rolling Stone’ Know It Declared Songwriting Dead?|first=Judy |last=Berman|date=August 17, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> Geeta Dayal from ''[[The Guardian]]'' accused "corporate sponsorship" in determining the list's content.<ref name="theguardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/aug/24/rolling-stones-greatest-songwriters-list-corporate-sponsorship-apple-music|title=The real peril in Rolling Stone's greatest songwriters wasn't the lack of diversity – it was the corporate sponsorship|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Geeta|last=Dayal|date=August 24, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> Tom Moon from [[NPR]] wrote that "This list represents another trip through the hagiographic, hermetically sealed [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame|rock hall of fame]], with the same stars you've been reading about in Rolling Stone since the dinosaur age."<ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2015/08/24/433206610/the-one-real-problem-with-rolling-stones-greatest-songwriters-of-all-time|first=Tom|last=Moon|publisher=[[NPR]]|title=The One Real Problem With Rolling Stone's 'Greatest Songwriters Of All Time'|date=August 24, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' editor Martin Chilton responded with a list of 100 best songwriters missed out by ''Rolling Stone'', including [[Cole Porter]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], [[Ewan MacColl]], [[Kate Bush]], and [[Ray Charles]].<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/what-to-listen-to/100-great-songwriters/|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=100 great songwriters not in the Rolling Stone list|date=May 17, 2016|first=Martin|last=Chilton|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref>
Jacqueline Cutler from ''[[New York Daily News]]'' agreed with the magazine for ranking [[Bob Dylan]] as the top songwriter.<ref name="nydailynews">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/bob-dylan-rolling-stone-greatest-songwriter-article-1.2325783|title=Bob Dylan is Rolling Stone’s greatest songwriter|work=[[New York Daily News]]|first=Jacqueline|last=Cutler|date=August 14, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> Jon Bream from ''[[Star Tribune]]'' praised the inclusion of songwriters from [[Minnesota]] and said that Dylan as a number-one songwriter is not surprising at all.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/dylan-tops-rolling-stone-s-rankings-of-best-songwriters-prince-is-no-18/321851631/|title=Dylan tops Rolling Stone's rankings of best songwriters; Prince is No. 18|first=Jon|last=Bream|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 14, 2015|accessdate=June 8, 2018}}</ref> Baby A. Gil from ''[[The Philippine Star]]'' reacted positively to the list, saying that "it is the best list of its type that I have come across and I like the fact that it arouses interest in sounds one may not have heard before or in a long time."<ref name="philstar">{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2015/08/31/1494062/greatest-songwriters-pop-era|title=The greatest songwriters of the pop era|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=August 31, 2015|first=Baby A.|last=Gil|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}</ref> Lori Melton from [[AXS (company)|AXS]] said that the list "reads like an iconic student body in a songwriting master class" and complimented the inclusion of female songwriters Carole King, Joni Mitchell, [[Dolly Parton]], [[Stevie Nicks]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Chrissie Hynde]], [[Loretta Lynn]], [[Lucinda Williams]], and [[Björk]], as well as [[Taylor Swift]] who is the youngest person on the list.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.axs.com/taylor-swift-makes-her-mark-on-rolling-stone-s-100-greatest-songwriter-63965|title=Taylor Swift makes her mark on Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Songwriters list|first=Lori|last=Melton|publisher=[[AXS (company)|AXS]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=June 8, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of best-selling music artists]] * [[Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time|The 100 Greatest Artists of All Time]], also from ''Rolling Stone'' magazine * [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time]], also from ''Rolling Stone'' magazine * [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time]], also from ''Rolling Stone'' magazine

[[File:Plakat mayakowski gross.jpg|thumb|[[Agitprop]] poster by Mayakovsky]] '''Russian Telegraph Agency''' ({{lang-ru|Российское телеграфное агентство}}, ''Rossiyskoye telegrafnoye agentstvo''), [[abbreviation|abbr.]] '''ROSTA''', was the [[State media|state]] [[news agency]] in [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] (1918-35). After the creation of [[Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union]] in 1925, it remained the news agency of Soviet Russia. Its name was associated with ''Rosta windows'' ({{lang-ru|Окна Роста}}, ''Okna Rosta'').
==Rosta windows== Rosta windows or satirical Rosta windows ({{lang-ru|Окна сатиры Роста}}, ''Okna satiry Rosta'') were [[stencil]]-replicated [[propaganda]] [[poster]]s created by artists and poets within the Rosta system, under the supervision of the Chief Committee of Political Education during 1919-21. Inheriting the [[Russia]]n design traditions of [[lubok]] and [[rayok]], the main topics were current political events. They were usually displayed in windows, hence the name.
The first Rosta window was created in Moscow by Mikhail Cheremnykh (1890-1962). He was soon joined by [[Vladimir Mayakovsky]], a popular and prolific author, [[Dmitry Moor]] (1883-1946), [[Amshey Nurenberg]] (1887-1979), [[Alexander Rodchenko]], [[Mikhail Volpin]] and others. Similar projects were performed in other Soviet cities. Cheremnykh and Mayakovsky, for example, produced a poster in 1921 satirising a [[French people|French]] delegation led by [[Joseph Noulens]].<ref>[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O74913/poster/ V&A Images]</ref>
The design featured graphical simplicity suitable for viewing from distance and often used [[lubok]]-styled sequences of pictures according to some plot, similar to modern [[comics]]. The posters were not printed but rather painted with cut-out stencils made from cardboard. Once the required number of posters was painted, the stencils were sent to another city and put in circulation throughout the Soviet Union.
During the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|World War II]], this approach was reproduced in Tass windows by [[Kukryniksy]].
==See also== * [[Media of Russia]]
